titleproper.value: Guide to the Julius Manson Papers <num>WAG.164</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-06-20T18:46:03</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

extent.value: in 40 record cartons, 1 folder in a shared box and 1 folder in a flat-file drawer

abstract.value: Julius J. Manson (1907-1988) was a New York City professor and labor mediator and arbitrator.  The Julius Manson Papers include notes, correspondence, publications, research materials, articles, and photographs and are primarily from the 1940s through the 1970s.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Julius Manson Papers; WAG 164; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Materials found in repository; provenance is unknown. The accession numbers associated with this colletion are 1986.007, 1986.013 and NPA.2001.003.

Manson was involved with the international Esperanto movement, representing the Universal Esperanto Association of the United Nations in the 1980s and 1990s.  He was a founding member of the Three Arrows Cooperative Society and served as its president during 1937-1938.  His first wife, Minnie Kaplan, died in 1941.  After World War II, he married Elizabeth Robinson Butzner.

The Julius Manson Papers primarily relate to Manson's work as a professor and labor mediator and arbitrator.  There are some materials related to his involvement in the movement for the international adoption of Esperanto.  Materials include notes, correspondence, publications, research materials, articles, and photographs and are primarily from the 1940s through the 1970s.

subject.value: Labor laws and legislation -- New York (State)
